docs.abstract: Ilene Cooper reviews book The Trolls by Polly Horvath (S)
docs.snippet: The Trolls   Written and illustrated   by Polly Horvath.   Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.   (Ages 8 to 12)

docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine what would happen if society could guarantee every poor person a path from poverty: an assured job at a sufficient wage, with child care and health care as well. How many would take it? How many would prosper? A decade ago, an unconventional band of reformers here set out to find the answer, and their discoveries offer an unsettling new look at the prospects of low-income families at a time of a national exodus from welfare.

headline.main: Project to Rescue Needy Stumbles Against the Persistence of Poverty

docs.abstract: Project New Hope, Milwaukee experiment in lifting people out of poverty by providing them guaranted job at sufficient wage, together with child and health care, suggests that inner-city poverty may be even harder to alleviate than is understood; has produced most comprehensive study of poor families of post-welfare age; recruited 677 low-income adults and made offer of jobs of 30 hours a week at guaranteed wage; only 27 percent stuck with jobs long enough to work way out of poverty and incomes were statistically no better than those in control group; project's clients showed no declines in depression and no growth in self-esteem, when compared with control group, despite conventional theory that going to work makes low-income adults feel better about themselves; photo (M)
